points: First meeting: 9 December 1946 at Constitution Hall (now Central Hall of Parliament).
Drafting time: 2 years, 11 months, 17 days.
Sessions/sittings: 11 sessions, total 165 days; 114 days on Draft Constitution discussion.
Total membership (original): 389 = 292 (provinces) + 93 (princely states) + 4 (Chief Commissioner’s provinces).
Female members in CA: 15.
Objective Resolution: moved 13 Dec 1946, adopted 22 Jan 1947.
Constitution adopted: 26 Nov 1949; enforced: 26 Jan 1950 (Republic Day).
Constitution Day: 26 November.
Correct sequence: Sovereign, Socialist, Secular, Democratic, Republic.
Preamble amended only once: 42nd Amendment (1976) added “Socialist”, “Secular” and changed “unity of the nation” to “unity and integrity of the nation”.
SSC common tags: “Political Horoscope” – K.M. Munshi; “Identity card” – N.A. Palkhivala; “Keynote” – Ernest Barker.
Independent judiciary: judiciary works without control/pressure from executive/legislature (so “independent judicial system” is correct).
Single citizenship (so “dual citizenship” is NOT a feature).
Universal adult franchise is a feature.
Amendment process = blend of rigidity and flexibility; quote asked in your set: K.C. Wheare (“variety in the amending process…”).
“Federation” word is not used, but India is a Union of States (Article 1).
New states: Article 2 (admission/establishment), Article 3 (formation/alteration); NOT Article 5.
Law-making: Union List → Parliament only; Concurrent List → both Parliament & States.
Emergencies are proclaimed by the President: National (Art. 352), President’s Rule (Art. 356), Financial (Art. 360).

Official language: Article 343(1) says Hindi in Devanagari; Official Languages Act 1963, Section 3 continues English (in addition to Hindi) for Union official purposes and Parliament from the appointed day (26 Jan 1965).
Republic; ideals of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity (Preamble): France
Law-making / legislative procedure: United Kingdom (UK)
Parliamentary democracy (Westminster model): United Kingdom (UK)
First-Past-The-Post (FPTP) election system: United Kingdom (UK)
Independence of judiciary: USA
Judicial review: USA
Fundamental Rights (often asked as “Charter of FR”): USA
Concurrent List: Australia
Ideal of Justice (social, economic, political) in Preamble; Fundamental Duties: USSR (now Russia)
Emergency provisions: Government of India Act, 1935
Amendment procedure: South Africa
Advisory jurisdiction of Supreme Court: Canada
Martial law concept (English common law); only mention is Article 34: UK / English common law
If the clue is Parliament/cabinet/PM/law-making procedure/FPTP, tick UK.
If the clue is Fundamental Rights / Judicial Review / Independence of Judiciary, tick USA.
Concurrent List = Australia, not Canada.
Amendment procedure = South Africa, while joint sitting + freedom of trade/commerce/intercourse = Australia (don’t mix).
Martial law is not defined in the Constitution; it’s linked to Article 34 and its origin is English common law.

Use these as "ranges" for quick MCQ elimination: Part III (FR) = Articles 12-35, Part IV (DPSP) = 36-51, Part V (Union) includes Union Executive 52-78 and Parliament 79-122, Part VI (States) = 152-237.

Other high-yield ranges from your file: Legislative relations (Part XI) 245-255, Elections (Part XV) 324-329, Language (Part XVII) 343-351, Amendment (Part XX) 368, Panchayats (Part IX) 243-243O, Municipalities (Part IXA) 243P-243ZG.
As of June 2023: 12 Schedules (1st-12th).
7th Schedule = Union/State/Concurrent Lists (division of powers; linked with Article 246 as mentioned in your file).
8th Schedule = 22 scheduled languages.
3rd Schedule = forms of oath/affirmation (President, Ministers, MPs/MLAs, Judges, CAG, etc.).
10th Schedule = Anti-defection (inserted by 52nd Amendment, 1985).
9th Schedule = laws placed beyond certain judicial challenges (added by 1st Amendment, 1951 - asked as a trap with 10th Schedule).
These are the "direct hit" Articles SSC repeats most.
Parliamentary form at Centre: Articles 74 & 75 (CoM aids/advises President; PM & Ministers appointment provisions).
Collective responsibility: Article 75(3) = Council of Ministers collectively responsible to the House of the People (Lok Sabha) (correcting the "753" style misprint in the file).
Conduct of Govt of India business: Article 77.
Parliament consists of: President + two Houses (Rajya Sabha & Lok Sabha) = Article 79.
Parliament & its proceedings (range): Articles 79-122.
Sessions of Parliament, prorogation, dissolution: Article 85.
Ministers + Attorney General can speak/participate in either House but no vote: Article 88.
Salaries/allowances of RS Chairman/Deputy + LS Speaker/Deputy: Article 97.
Separate secretarial staff for each House: Article 98.
Money Bill not introduced in Rajya Sabha: Article 109.
Annual Financial Statement (Budget): Article 112.
Language in Parliament: Article 120.
President's Ordinance power is Article 123 (and is in Part V, Chapter III - not in Parliament chapter).
Qualifications for Lok Sabha member: Article 84.
Bicameral Parliament (asked as "which Article provides bicameralism"): Article 79 (because it creates two Houses).

notes.subtopic: States + Centre-State control (Part VI + key links)
points: Focus here is Governor/CM, State Legislature basics, and Union directions.
Governor can be appointed for two or more states: Article 153 (amended to allow this; asked directly).
Executive power of Governor: Article 154.
CM & Ministers appointment in state: Article 164(1); collective responsibility to Legislative Assembly: Article 164(2).
Advocate-General of state: Article 165 (duty to advise govt on legal matters is a common phrasing).
Conduct of business of state govt; executive action in Governor's name: Article 166 (often asked as 166(1)).
State Legislature provisions (range): Articles 168-212 in Part VI.
Qualification for membership of State Legislature: Article 173.
Governor's right to address/send messages to House(s): Article 175.
Governor can reserve a Bill for President: Article 200 (President's action then is under Article 201 - asked as a trap).
Governor's ordinance power during recess: Article 213.
High Court for each state: Article 214; High Court as court of record: Article 215 (asked as linked facts).
Union control over States in certain cases (directions so state executive doesn't impede Union): Article 257.
Duty of Union to protect states against external aggression/internal disturbance: Article 355.
Special provisions: Arunachal Pradesh (law & order responsibility of Governor) = Article 371H; Sikkim = Article 371F.
NCT of Delhi (Legislative Assembly): Article 239AA.
This block gives you max score from 1-line Article hits.
Fundamental Rights structure (for "range" questions): Part III = Articles 12-35, and it's often called "Magna Carta of India" in SSC phrasing.
Freedom of speech & expression: Article 19(1)(a) (standard format; not "191a").
Right to move freely: Article 19(1)(d).
Double jeopardy: Article 20(2).
Right to life & personal liberty: Article 21 (your file also links major cases as examples).
Prohibition of child labour in factories/mines/hazardous work: Article 24.
Minorities' educational institutions: Article 30.
Right to constitutional remedies: Article 32.
Parliament can restrict/abrogate FR for armed forces etc.: Article 33.
Reservation in promotion (SC/ST): Article 16(4A) (77th Amendment is mentioned in your file as context).
President/Governor protection from court proceedings for official acts: Article 361.
Right to property is a legal right under Article 300A (not a Fundamental Right).
Directive Principles (DPSP): Part IV = Articles 36-51, non-justiciable but "fundamental in governance" idea is tested.
DPSP "fundamental in governance; duty of state to apply" (common SSC line): Article 37.
Welfare State idea commonly linked in your file: Article 38.
Material resources distributed for common good: Article 39(b).
Equal pay for equal work (men & women): Article 39(d).
Village Panchayats organisation: Article 40 (also tagged as a Gandhian principle in your file).
Just and humane conditions of work + maternity relief: Article 42.
Cottage industries; living wage etc.: Article 43 (and related add-ons 43A/43B appear in your file).
Promotion of educational/economic interests of SC/ST & weaker sections: Article 46.
Raise nutrition/standard of living; improve public health: Article 47.
Environment/forests/wildlife protection: Article 48A (added by 42nd Amendment is noted in your file).
These are the "scattered but frequent" one-liners.
Supreme Court is a court of record: Article 129 (this is exactly what your MCQ #108 tests).
Seat of Supreme Court: Article 130.
Supreme Court can review its judgments/orders: Article 137.
Law declared by Supreme Court binding: Article 141 (asked as a trap with 142/143/144).
Complete justice / discretionary power often asked: Article 142.
President can consult SC (advisory jurisdiction): Article 143.
Civil & judicial authorities act in aid of SC: Article 144.
Elections: Article 324 = superintendence, direction and control of elections vested in Election Commission.
Article 327 = Parliament's power to make provisions on elections to legislatures.
Article 329 = bar to interference by courts in electoral matters (Your match-the-following in the file is 1→324, 2→327, 3→329; keep this as a fixed map).
Finance Commission: Article 280.
UPSC/SPSC base: Article 315(1) (Union + each State PSC).
Removal/suspension of PSC member: Article 317.
PSC reports: Article 323.
CAG block: Articles 148-151; duties/powers: Article 149; audit reports laid before President: Article 151.
Attorney-General for India is Article 76, and the "right of audience in all courts" is Article 76(3).
Official language of Union (Hindi in Devanagari): Article 343(1).
Proceedings in Supreme Court & every High Court in English: Article 348(1).
Special Officer for linguistic minorities: Article 350B.
Directive for development/spread of Hindi: Article 351; also linked with Article 344(1) in 8th Schedule questions.

Article 368 (Part XX) gives Parliament the power to amend the Constitution using (i) special majority, or (ii) special majority + ratification by at least half of the State legislatures (only for specified matters).
Some provisions can be changed by simple majority (outside Article 368 route), and SSC commonly asks these as traps: Article 2, Article 3, Article 169.
Fundamental Rights (Part III) like Article 21 cannot be amended by simple majority; they require the Article 368 procedure.
91st Amendment Act, 2003: Total Union Council of Ministers (PM included) ≤ 15% of Lok Sabha strength; in States, CM+ministers ≤ 15% of Assembly strength and not less than 12.
42nd Amendment Act, 1976 (“Mini-Constitution”): Added “socialist” and “secular” and changed “unity” to “unity and integrity” in the Preamble.
42nd Amendment (DPSP change-set): Added Articles 39A, 43A, 48A and also made changes to Article 39(f) (in SSC, this is sometimes counted as “4 DPSP provisions affected”).
42nd Amendment (Fundamental Duties): Inserted Part IV-A containing Article 51A (not “Article 51”).
86th Amendment Act, 2002: Inserted Article 21A (free & compulsory education for ages 6-14), modified Article 45, and added Article 51A(k) (duty of parents/guardians).
61st Amendment Act, 1988: Reduced voting age from 21 to 18 by amending Article 326.
101st Amendment Act, 2016: Inserted Article 279A (GST Council) via the 101st Amendment.
103rd Amendment Act, 2019: Enabled 10% EWS reservation by inserting Article 15(6) and Article 16(6).
73rd Amendment Act, 1992: 3-tier PRIs; intermediate level may not be constituted in a state with population not exceeding 20 lakhs (so “3-tier above 20 lakhs” is the exam line).
26th Amendment Act, 1971: Abolished privy purses and led to omission of Articles 291 and 362 (asked as a direct one-liner).
88th Amendment Act, 2003: Added “taxes on services” by inserting Article 268A and Entry 92C (Union List) (SSC often asks “which amendment added service tax subject”).
Use this as your direct “Answer key with 1-line logic” (same order as your JSON), and treat the above block as the concept layer.
163: Part IV-A inserted by 42nd; it contains Article 51A.
164: 42nd affected DPSP via 39A, 43A, 48A + change to 39(f) (SSC answer may be “Four” in that framing).
166: GST Council → 101st, Article 279A.
173: Article 21A → 86th.
174: “Secular” added to Preamble → 42nd.
175: 73rd, 3-tier above 20 lakh population.
184: Voting age 18 → 61st, Article 326.
199: “Taxes on services” → 88th.
170: EWS reservation basis → 103rd (Articles 15(6), 16(6)).

A few items in your list are ordinary Acts/Bills (current affairs/static mix), so read them as “year + which Act amended”: LLP (Amendment) Bill 2021 → LLP Act 2008; Family Courts (Amendment) Act 2022 → Family Courts Act 1984; UAPA effective from 1967.
Fundamental Duties are in Part IV-A, Article 51A, inserted by the 42nd Amendment (1976), and the idea is commonly linked to the former USSR/Russia.
The 11th duty (parents/guardians to provide education to children aged 6-14) was added by the 86th Amendment (2002) as Article 51A(k).

SSC frequently tests duty-mapping scenarios from your file: protect environment (51A(g)), develop scientific temper (51A(h)), safeguard public property/abjure violence (51A(i)), strive for excellence (51A(j)), promote harmony/brotherhood & dignity of women (51A(e)).
Fundamental Rights are in Part III (Articles 12-35), and SSC also asks that this rights framework is inspired largely by the USA.

High-yield one-liners from your set: Article 21 covers life & personal liberty (speedy trial is read under Article 21 in SSC framing), Article 23 prohibits trafficking/forced labour, Article 24 prohibits child labour below 14 in factories/mines/hazardous work.
Double jeopardy is Article 20(2) (not “Article 202”), and Article 20 overall is “protection in respect of conviction for offences.”
Right to Education is Article 21A (added by 86th Amendment, 2002) for children aged 6-14.
Religion & education trap: Article 28(1) prohibits religious instruction in an educational institution wholly maintained out of State funds.
Article 32 is the Fundamental Right to move the Supreme Court for enforcement of Fundamental Rights, and Article 226 gives High Courts writ jurisdiction (often asked as “similar to Art. 32”).
High Courts under Article 226 can issue writs not only for Fundamental Rights but also for other legal rights, so its scope is broader than Article 32 in exams.
The 5 writs you're being tested on are: Habeas Corpus, Mandamus, Prohibition, Certiorari, Quo Warranto (with standard one-line meanings exactly like your MCQs).
In SSC-style questions, Articles 20 and 21 are treated as the Fundamental Rights that cannot be suspended even during Emergency (common direct MCQ).
Your file contains an incorrect mapping “double jeopardy = Article 202”; the correct provision is Article 20(2).

One MCQ/explanation in your file treats Fundamental Duties as “statutory”; strictly, Fundamental Duties are constitutional (Part IV-A, Article 51A) and are non-justiciable (not directly enforceable in court), though laws can be made to enforce related behavior.
If any question claims FRs are borrowed from Britain, treat it as wrong for SSC: the standard answer is USA for Fundamental Rights.

notes: Hilton Young Commission. It is also known as the Royal Commission on Indian Currency and Finance, was established in 1926. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is India's central bank and regulatory body overseeing the Indian banking system. It manages the control, issuance, and supply of the Indian rupee. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) was established on April 1, 1935, in accordance with the provisions of the      Reserve Bank of India Act, 1934.

PK Thungon Committee: P.K. Thungan Committee recommended a constitutional amendment for regular elections, specific functions, and funding for local government institutions. Ashok Mehta Committee: It was set up in 1977 by the Janata government, studied the Panchayat Raj system in India. Balwant Rai Mehta Committee: It recommended decentralizing power and functions at the divisional and sub-divisional levels. Justice Verma Committee: It was formed to suggest changes to criminal law for faster trials and tougher punishments for those accused of sexual assault against women.

Justice Verma Committee. The committee was set up in 1999. It identified the existence of following legal provisions - Prevention of Insults to National Honour Act (1971), Protection of Civil Right Act (1955), Representation of People Act (1951), Wildlife Protection Act (1972) and Forest Conservation Act (1980).

Swaran Singh Committee (1976) originally recommended eight Fundamental Duties under Article 51A of the Indian Constitution. However, at the time of incorporation, ten duties were added to Part IV-A by the 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976. Initially, there were 10 duties, and one more was added by the 86th Constitutional Amendment Act, 2002, making a total of 11 duties.

Dutt Committee. The Hazari Committee was a committee in India that studied the industrial licensing procedure under the Industries (Development and Regulation) Act, 1951. Abhijit Sen Committee (2002) - Long Term Food Policy. The Gadgil commission was formed to study the impact of population pressure, climate change and development activities on the Western Ghats.

Sinho commission: Constituted in 2005, and submitted its report in 2010. In 2019, the Cabinet decided to amend the Constitution (103rd Amendment) to provide reservation to EWS. Sarkaria Commission (1983) - Reviewed center-state relations. Kelkar Commission (1953) - Also known as the First Backward Classes Commission. Mandal Commission (1979) - The Second Socially and Educationally Backward Classes Commission.

Justice PV Reddi. The second National judicial Pay Commission was formed in 2017 due to the supreme court’s order in the all India judges association case, under article 32, i.e., constitutional remedies. Justice Verma Committee was constituted to recommend amendments to the Criminal Law so as to provide for quicker trial and enhanced punishment for criminals accused of committing sexual assault against women. The Committee submitted its report on January 23, 2013.

Sarkaria Commission Report - This Commission is to examine and review the working of the existing arrangements between the Union and States as per the Constitution of India. Tej Bahadur Sapru Report (1945) - It related to political and civil rights of the minorities.

Estimation of poverty. Rangarajan Committee - To Review the Methodology for Measurement of Poverty in the country constituted by the Planning Commission in June 2012 has submitted its report on 30th June 2014. As per the report submitted by C Rangarajan Committee: Persons spending below Rs. 47 a day in cities should be considered poor. Committee related to poverty: Planning Commission Expert Group (1962), VM Dandekar and N Rath committee (1971), Y.K. Alagh Committee (1979), Lakdawala Committee (1993), Suresh Tendulkar Committee (2005).

Sarkaria commission (1983).      The States Reorganisation Commission (Fazal Ali Commission, 1953). Rajmannar commission set up by the then DMK Government of Tamil Nadu in 1969 under the Chairmanship of Dr P.V. Rajamanar.

MN Venkatachaliah Commission was set up by Government resolution in 2000 to Review the Working of the Constitution. He got Padma Vibhushan In 2004. Justice U.C.Banerjee headed the Commission report on Godhra incident.

This commission was established in India in 1979 by the Janata Party government under Prime Minister Morarji Desai. It was headed by BP Mandal. Parliament

points: The legislative organ of the Union government is the Parliament.
Parliament is bicameral (Lok Sabha + Rajya Sabha) and works with the President as part of the parliamentary framework in SSC notes.
Citizenship: Article 11 empowers Parliament to regulate citizenship by law (Part II: Articles 5-11).
“Devices of parliamentary proceedings” asked in your file include Half-an-hour discussion, Zero Hour, and Short duration (2-hour) discussion; “Full-day discussion” is marked as NOT a device.
Question Hour = first hour of a sitting for questions/answers (your file tests this directly).
Correction you should remember: Zero Hour is not the first hour; it is the informal time immediately after Question Hour (common SSC trap).
Private Member's Bill: a bill introduced by a non-minister (private member).
Money Bill: Rajya Sabha must return it to Lok Sabha within 14 days (with or without recommendations); otherwise it is deemed passed in the Lok Sabha form.
Speaker's certificate: for a Money Bill, the Speaker of Lok Sabha certifies it (your MCQ uses this).
Most powerful tool for executive accountability (as per your file): No-confidence motion, moved only in Lok Sabha; it needs support of 50 members for admission.
Max gap between two sessions of State Legislature = 6 months (linked to Article 174 in your file).

notes.subtopic: State legislature quick facts (from the same file)
points: Legislative Council (Vidhan Parishad): permanent House; members' term 6 years, and 1/3 retire every 2 years.
Composition pointers tested: 1/12 elected by graduates (3 years standing), 1/12 by teachers, 1/3 by local bodies, 1/3 by MLAs, 1/6 nominated by Governor.
Vidhan Sabha minimum age is 25 years (so the statement “21 years” is incorrect).
Language in State Legislature is governed by Article 210 (official language(s) of the state / Hindi / English, and Speaker/Chairman may permit mother tongue).

Your file's statement “Only Supreme Court can inquire into State Legislature proceedings” is wrong; courts are barred from questioning validity of proceedings on procedural irregularity grounds under Article 212.

In Q285 wording, it says “Money bill under Article 111”; treat this as a framing error—Article 111 is President's assent, while Money Bill definition/certification is tied to Article 110 (common SSC confusion).

topic: President, Vice President and Prime Minister

points: Article 54: Election of President (electoral college = elected MPs + elected MLAs).
Article 56: Term of office of President (and he continues until successor enters office).
Article 57: President is eligible for re-election.
Article 59: Conditions of President's office; crucial line—President is entitled without payment of rent to official residences (so any option saying “NOT entitled without payment of rent” is wrong).
Article 60: Oath/affirmation of President.
Article 61: Impeachment procedure; your file has a common trap—charges must be signed by not less than 1/4 members (not 1/3) and notice is 14 days (not 30 days).
Article 123: Ordinance-making power of President (when Parliament not in session).
Article 111: President's assent/veto over bills (pocket veto concept is asked in your file).
Article 63: “There shall be a Vice-President of India.”
Article 64: VP is ex-officio Chairman of Rajya Sabha.
Article 66: Election of Vice-President (electoral college = members of both Houses of Parliament; SSC often notes both elected + nominated participate).
Removal: your file flags this—VP is not removed by the President; removal is by a resolution of Rajya Sabha agreed to by Lok Sabha (SSC asks this as “INCORRECT statement”).
PM appointment: Article 75 (PM appointed by President).
“Linchpin of government”: PM acts as link between President–CoM–Parliament (asked as a concept MCQ).
Shortest-serving PM: your file gives Gulzarilal Nanda (acting PM, 13 days) as the “shortest” in many SSC keys; sometimes SSC also asks among full PMs, but follow the paper's framing.
Governor is appointed by President: Article 155; minimum age 35: Article 157.
Governor's oath: Article 159, taken before Chief Justice of the High Court (or senior-most judge available).
State CoM hold office during Governor's pleasure: Article 164(1); Governor appoints ministers on CM's advice.
Prorogation/dissolution of State Legislature: Article 174(2) (Governor can prorogue, and dissolve the Assembly).

President's Rule: Article 356; your file says “initially 6 months”—the key exam fact is proclamation must be approved by Parliament within 2 months, and then extensions happen with approvals (your file's wording mixes these—revise carefully).
91st Amendment inserted Article 164(1A): total ministers (including CM) ≤ 15% of Assembly strength, and not less than 12.
So your Q330 “minimum strength of CoM in a state” = 12 (as per the proviso).
Rajya Sabha nominated members = 12 under Article 80(1)(a); your file's explanation wrongly says “Fourth Schedule Articles 41…” (that is incorrect wording).
“Money Bill in State Assembly with prior permission of Governor”: the correct phrasing is prior recommendation of the Governor (Article 207/198 area), not “permission” (SSC accepts “Governor”).
Transfer of HC judge: Article 222; order is by President (as your file says).

The Supreme Court's original jurisdiction covers disputes between the Government of India and one or more States, between the Union plus one/more States on one side and other State(s) on the other, and between two or more States, when the dispute involves a question on which a legal right depends (Article 131).
This “original jurisdiction” is exclusive, meaning such inter-government disputes go directly to the Supreme Court (not via lower courts).
The Supreme Court's appellate jurisdiction is typically invoked through constitutional/civil/criminal appeal routes, often including a High Court certificate where required (common SSC framing).
The maximum strength (excluding the CJI) was increased from 30 to 33 by the Supreme Court (Number of Judges) Amendment Bill/Act, 2019, i.e., CJI + 33 other judges = 34 total.
Article 124 is the constitutional basis for the Supreme Court's establishment and composition (SSC asks this as “there shall be a Supreme Court of India”).
A judge of the Supreme Court can be removed only on grounds of proved misbehaviour or incapacity, using the Constitution's prescribed high-threshold process (SSC keywords).

notes.subtopic: Writs: Prohibition vs Certiorari (most common trap)
points: Prohibition is a preventive writ: it stops a lower court/tribunal from continuing proceedings when it is acting without or in excess of jurisdiction (issued while the matter is pending).
Certiorari is a corrective writ: it is issued after a lower court/tribunal has passed an order, to quash that order for jurisdictional/legal error.
The “law declared by the Supreme Court is binding on all courts within the territory of India” is Article 141 (standard SSC line).
The first signed motion to remove a sitting Supreme Court judge is commonly referenced as the 1991 motion relating to Justice V. Ramaswami (SSC/GK framing).
FC is a constitutional body under Article 280, constituted by the President.
Composition: 1 Chairperson + 4 other members (so “other members except Chairman” = 4).
It is constituted every 5 years (or earlier if needed).
Article 281: The President lays FC recommendations (with an explanatory memorandum on action taken) before each House of Parliament.
FC recommendations are advisory (not legally binding), though governments generally follow them with reasons if deviating.
Election Commission of India (ECI) is a constitutional body under Part XV (Articles 324-329) (standard SSC framing).
ECI was constituted on 25 January 1950.
Tenure commonly asked in SSC: 6 years or up to age 65 years (whichever earlier) for the CEC/ECs (as used in exam keys).

“Multi-member ECI” timeline (most asked as a fact): first time two additional Election Commissioners were appointed on 16 Oct 1989 (short period), and a 3-member commission has functioned since 1 Oct 1993.
State Election Commission (Panchayat elections): Article 243K vests superintendence/control of Panchayat elections in the SEC, with the State Election Commissioner appointed by the Governor.
NHRC is a statutory body under the Protection of Human Rights Act, 1993.
NHRC Chairperson tenure (after amendment): 3 years or up to age 70 years (whichever earlier), and eligible for re-appointment.
National Commission for Women (NCW) is a statutory body under the National Commission for Women Act, 1990; the Act's enforcement date is 31-01-1992.
The Registrar General and Census Commissioner, India comes under the Ministry of Home Affairs.

Free legal aid (NALSA framework): Section 12 of the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987 includes eligibility such as SC/ST, victims of trafficking/begar (Art. 23), industrial workmen, and victims of mass disaster/violence/flood/drought/earthquake/industrial disaster (among others).
The state/official language of Bangladesh is Bangla (Bengali).
Sri Lanka became independent on 4 February 1948.
The Constitution in force since 7 September 1978 defines the country as the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka.
The Indian Peace Keeping Force (IPKF) was sent to Sri Lanka in 1987 under the Indo-Sri Lanka Accord framework.
Nepal's current constitution came into effect on 20 September 2015 (often asked as “first democratic constitution” in SSC-style GK).

Punjab's Legislative Council was abolished by the Punjab Legislative Council (Abolition) Act, 1969, which was brought into force by Central Government notification (commonly cited as 7 January 1970; some exam keys write 1 January 1970).
“Rule of Law” doctrine is ascribed to A.V. Dicey (Albert Venn Dicey).
Dicey's core pillars (SSC-style): supremacy of law, equality before law, predominance of legal spirit.
NPR was created under the Citizenship Act, 1955 and the Citizenship Rules, 2003.
The Citizenship Rules, 2003 were framed under the Citizenship Act, 1955 and contain provisions connected with creating population/citizenship registers (SSC framing).
The concept of PIL is commonly traced to the USA (modern public interest law movement).
In India, the “seed” of PIL is widely credited to Justice V.R. Krishna Iyer in Mumbai Kamgar Sabha v. Abdul Thai (1976) (SSC's most repeated line).
The Indian High Courts Act was passed in 1861.
India follows a multi-party system; parties are generally discussed as national and state/regional in exam notes.
Panchayati Raj institutions are not present in some North-East states due to special provisions; common exam list: Nagaland, Meghalaya, Mizoram.
